ygData.subject: Re: Timestepping through neurons in NEAT and HyperNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Todd, As Ken Llyod pointed out, there are many definitions of a timestep when activating a neural network.  Which definition you choose generally depends on

Subject: Re: Timestepping through neurons in NEAT and HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=274910130; y=Lz_xKzL-75Ss_2CbXu1QnfD-FyudRiAcJtDAFMZIK5UaWfbC
X-Yahoo-Profile: ddambroeplex

Todd,

As Ken Llyod pointed out, there are many definitions of a "timestep"=
 when activating a neural network.  Which definition you choose generally d=
epends on the type of problem you are trying to solve.  For example, a navi=
gating robot will receive new inputs and need to produce new outputs on eve=
ry timestep and the timesteps may be related, so a timestep may just be mov=
ing activation the length of one connection.  Whereas in a classification p=
roblem you are only interested in the final output of the neural network an=
d the order of the data is not important, so a timestep would be activating=
 the network without changing the inputs until a solution is produced.  

Q=
uerying a CPPN in HyperNEAT is much like a classification problem (i.e. wha=
t weight should this connection be?) so it uses that definition of a timest=
ep.  Personally I have seen several activation schemes used, although I am =
sure there are more: activating the network a fixed number of times, activa=
ting the network some calculated number of times to ensure all signals prop=
agate to the output, or activating the network until it relaxes (i.e. the n=
euron signals stop changing within some delta).  The important thing that l=
inks these methods is that the inputs of the network do not change until th=
e connection weight is assigned.  At that point network signals are cleared=
 and a new input is provided.  The CPPN may still have recurrent connection=
s, but they are cleared every time there is a new input.  By activating the=
 CPPN in this way, the order that the connections are queried is irrelevant=
.

David

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "jtoddowen" <jtoddowen@...> wrote:
>=

> Please correct me if I'm wrong.  My understanding of recurrence and
> ne=
uron links in NEAT is that during each timestep new input data is
> present=
ed to the ANN and travels to the next neuron until ultimately
> reaching th=
e output.  Therefore, using the NEAT structure at
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~=
kstanley/neat.html
> <http://www.cs.ucf.edu/%7Ekstanley/neat.html>  it woul=
d take 3 timesteps
> for activation from input 1 to traverse neurons 16, 26=
9 and then 5,
> although data is also going directly from 1 to 5 (through a=
 direct link)
> in one step.
> 
> If the above is correct, how do the Hyper=
NEAT timesteps work?  Using the
> model from http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperN=
EATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> <http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.h=
tml%20>  does [0, 0.5,
> 1 , 1] get input, then [0.5, 0, 1, 0.5] next?  If =
so, it would seem to
> me the order you traversed the points in the substra=
te would affect the
> output.  Or, do you keep the "state" of each link act=
ivation stored
> separately from one input substrate to another (one checke=
rboard play to
> another); in other words, are you keeping (4096 + 64) "sta=
tes" for each
> timestep?
> 
> --Todd
